dc:description: The NOG gene is located on chromosome 17 at 17q22 and encodes a secreted homodimeric glycoprotein called noggin that is essential for normal bone and joint development. NOG was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant NOG-related Symphalangism Spectrum Disorder in 1999 (Gong et al., 1999, PMID: 10080184). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found no difference in molecular mechanism, phenotypic variability, and inheritance pattern of the five disease assertions. For these reasons, the following diseases have been lumped into one entity; proximal symphalangism (MIM 185800), multiple synostoses syndrome 1 (MIM 186500), tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome (MIM 186570), stapes ankylosis with broad thumbs and toes (MIM 184460), and brachydactyly type B2 (MIM 611377). The new term encompassing these five overlapping clinical syndromes is NOG-related Symphalangism Spectrum Disorder (NOG-SSD) (MONDO: 0100521, Potti et al., 2011, PMID: 21538686). NOG-SSD is characterized by proximal symphalangism, conductive deafness caused by stapes ankylosis, ocular abnormality such as hyperopia and strabismus, and characteristic facial features including a broad, tubular-shaped nose and a thin upper vermilion (PMID: 21538686). The term NOG-SSD aids in the clinical diagnosis and evaluation of affected individuals.Two missense, five frameshift, and three nonsense variants reported in ten probands in four publications (PMID: 12089654, 15699718, 21358557, 25241334) are included in this curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is known to be loss of function which leads to misfolding, decreased stability, decreased affinity to bone morphogenic proteins (BMPs), or reduced/undetectable secretion of noggin. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by biochemical data, functional alteration assay, and mouse animal models (PMID: 9603738, 12478285, 1156247, 18096605). In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between NOG and autosomal dominant NOG-related Symphalangism Spectrum Disorder. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. The classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on the meeting date July 5, 2023 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: Patients diagnosed with Autosomal Dominant NOG-related Symphalangism Spectrum Disorder have skeletal abnormalities such as proximal interphalangeal joints, carpal and tarsal bone fusion, brachydactyly, hypoplastic, and absent middle phalanges. This phenotype is consistent with the abnormality of bone morphology seen in chick limb development with which is presented in this paper.
evidence.rdfs:label: Groppe - Biochemical Functional Assay

evidence.dc:description: Noggin missense mutations affected the protein’s ability to form secreted disulfide-linked dimers in COS-7 Cells. The noggin mutants p.Pro223Leu, p.Gly189Cys had decreased levels of dimeric noggin compared with wild type. Both wild-type and mutant noggin dimers were capable of binding to BMPs. The p.Trp217Gly did not appear secreted as either a monomer or a dimer. Cotransfection studies in COS-7 cells indicated that mutant polypeptide did not interfere with the dimerization and secretion of wild-type protein.
evidence.rdfs:label: Marcelino-Functional Alteration

evidence.dc:description:
NOG-SSD is humans is mainly characterized by skeletal defects and synostoses, which include conductive hearing loss. Noggin is an antagonist of bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs), and balanced levels of BMPs and Noggin are required for proper skeletal formation. Depending on
the genetic background, some of the Nog1/2 mice display mild hearing loss, that is, conductive in nature. This mouse model data strongly suggest that the autosomal dominant disorders associated with NOG mutations are due to haploinsufficiency of NOGGIN.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hwang - NonHuman Model Organism (Mouse)

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded from the default score of 2.0 to 0.5 as per curation discussion and expert panel's suggestion.
NOG-SSD is mainly characterized by proximal symphalangim. Brunet et al., 1998 mouse model  expression of noggin gene demonstrated that noggin is essential for proper skeletal development.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brunet - Nonhuman Model Organism (Mouse)
Lee Family 2

member.rdfs:label: Lee - Family 2 Patient 6
member.detectionMethod: Genetic testing of the NOG gene revealed a novel frameshift mutation c.261 262ins(G) p.Pro88Alafs*94
member.phenotypeFreeText: conductive hearing disturbance, facial dysmorphism, including a flat nasal root, a bulbous nasal tip, malar flattening, small jaw, short thumbs, big toes, stenosis of the cervical and lumbar spinal canal, distal phalanges of both fingers were short and the left capitate and hamate were fused, metatarsal and phalangeal bones of both big toes were short, and fused middle and distal phalanges of both fourth and fifth toes .

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: conductive hearing disturbance, facial dysmorphism, including a flat nasal root, a bulbous nasal tip, malar flattening, small jaw, short thumbs, big toes, stenosis of the cervical and lumbar spinal canal, distal phalanges of both fingers were short and the left capitate and hamate were fused, metatarsal and phalangeal bones of both big toes were short, and fused middle and distal phalanges of both fourth and fifth toes .

evidence.dc:description: This is an AD with less than 4 segregations.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brown - Family G

member.rdfs:label: Brown - VI-1
member.detectionMethod: Venous-blood samples were obtained from 2 family members. The NOG coding region was amplified from genomic DNA by PCR and then bidirectionally sequenced using an automated DNA sequencer
member.phenotypeFreeText: minor skeletal anomalies, Posteriorly sloping forehead, Symmetrically short distal thumb Phalanges, Broad, hemicylindrical nose with bulbous tip and short philtrum, conductive hearing loss of a moderate to severe degree

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: minor skeletal anomalies, Posteriorly sloping forehead, Symmetrically short distal thumb Phalanges, Broad, hemicylindrical nose with bulbous tip and short philtrum, conductive hearing loss of a moderate to severe degree

evidence.rdfs:label: Thomeer - Turkish Family

member.rdfs:label: Thomeer Turkish Family - II:1
member.detectionMethod: DNA was isolated from peripheral blood lymphocytes using standard methods. The NOG gene was investigated using primers flanking the coding regions for amplification, and subsequent sequence analysis of the resulting fragments was performed with the BigDye Terminator kit and an ABI 3730 automated sequence analyzer.
member.phenotypeFreeText: hearing impairment, slightly dysmorphic face,broad nasal bridge, ptosis, thin upper lip, and asymmetry of the mouth,  bilateral restricted movement of the PIP joints of the 5th finger

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: hearing impairment, slightly dysmorphic face,broad nasal bridge, ptosis, thin upper lip, and asymmetry of the mouth,  bilateral restricted movement of the PIP joints of the 5th finger,facial dysmorphisms and a bilateral absence of the palmar flexion creases of the PIP joints of the fifth fingers

evidence.dc:description: Mutation analysis by sequencing the protein-coding region of the NOG gene revealed mutations in the affected members
evidence.rdfs:label: Weekamp - Family A

member.rdfs:label: Weekamp - Case A: III-5
member.detectionMethod: DNA from lymphocytes was isolated as described. Mutation analysis by sequencing the protein-coding region of the NOG gene revealed mutations
member.phenotypeFreeText: hemicylindrical shape or hypoplasia of the alae of the nose, small eyes, impairment on the thoracic or lumbar level, Dorsal extension of the fingers of the left hand was impaired, extremely broad distal phalanx of the thumb without brachytelephalangia, clinodactyly in the second digit of the left hand, syndactyly on the second and third toes bilaterally, fusion of vertebrae C6 and C7 and conspicuous short and broad metatarsal bones of the first toes

member.detectionMethod: DNA was isolated from peripheral blood lymphocytes using standard methods. The NOG gene was investigated using primers flanking the coding regions for amplification, and subsequent sequence analysis of the resulting fragments was performed with the BigDye Terminator kit and an ABI 3730 automated sequence analyzer.
member.phenotypeFreeText: bilateral conductive hearing impairment,slight facial dysmorphism (a small nose, under-projection of the nasal tip, short columella, sloping forehead)

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: bilateral conductive hearing impairment,slight facial dysmorphism (a small nose, under-projection of the nasal tip, short columella, sloping forehead)

evidence.rdfs:label: Weekamp - Family C

member.rdfs:label: Weekamp - Case C: II:1
member.detectionMethod: DNA from lymphocytes was isolated as described. Mutation analysis by sequencing the protein-coding region of the NOG gene revealed mutations in the affected members of all three families.
member.phenotypeFreeText: long stature, small eyes, short and broad distal phalanges of the thumbs, slight degree of syndactyly between the second and third digits of the left hand and also between the third and fourth digits bilaterally, proximal symphalangism of the fifth digits in both hands, brachytelephalangia of the left first toe, and both first toes were broad, bilaterally, the third and second toes were long, with short and broad distal phalanges of the second and third toes, syndactyly between the second and third toes in both feet

member.detectionMethod: DNA from lymphocytes was isolated as described. Mutation analysis by sequencing the protein-coding region of the NOG gene revealed mutations in the affected members

evidence.rdfs:label: Lee Family 3

member.rdfs:label: Lee - Family 2 III-4
member.detectionMethod: A mutation study for the NOG, GDF5, and FGF9 genes was performed. Both father and son had the novel NOG missense variant
member.phenotypeFreeText: a bulbous nasal tip with a flat nasal bridge, normal hearing and vision, mild hypoplasia of the distal fingers with short and flat nails, limited extension in the distal interphalangeal joints, Pes planovalgus in both feet. Toes short and stiff in motion, symphalangism of the proximal interphalangeal joints, hypoplasia of the middle phalanges, fusions of the carpal bones, hypoplastic middle phalanges, talonavicular fusion, osseous fusions of cuneiforms with metatarsals, absence of cuboid bone

evidence.dc:description: Genetic testing of the NOG, GDF5, and FGF9 genes was performed. A novel nonsense mutation, c.452C>A (p.Ser151*) was found in the NOG gene in patients 1–5 in this family
evidence.rdfs:label: Lee Family 1

member.rdfs:label: Lee - Family 1 III-2
member.detectionMethod: Genetic testing of the NOG, GDF5, and FGF9 genes was performed.
member.phenotypeFreeText: progressive lumbar radiculopathy, limited neck motion, facial dysmorphism, hypotelorism, a flat nasal root, bulbous nasal tip, malar flattening, an asymmetric mouth, a small jaw, bilateral conductive hearing loss, hyperopia, short thumbs and great toes, narrowing of the cervical and lumbar spinal canals with stenotic neural foraminas, severe atrophy of the spinal cord, short distal phalanges with symphalangism between the proximal and middle phalanges of both fifth fingers, great toes; short and broad metatarsals and phalanges, symphalangism in both 4–5th toes, tarsal bone synostoses
